This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1906
PAN-ISLAMISM IN NORTH AFRICA.

M. André Mévil, the well-known French journalist, publishes an interesting article in the "Echo de Paris" on the Pan-Islamic pro- paganda and its effect upon Algeria and Morocco, at the outset of which he makes a pointed reference to M. Jonnart, the Gover- nor-General of Algeria. Without saying that his information is derived from M. Jonnart, he gives it as coming from a good souce, and M. Mévil is known as a serious journalist. The article begins by mentioning the report that M. Jonnart is to attend the next Cabinet Council, which is an indication that the Fovernment desires to consult him probably on the serious question of the Moroccan frontier, which is closely connected with that of Morocco itself. Both, it says, react directly upon Algeria, where they serve as a pretext for an agitation "directed from Constantinople and Cairo by way of Berlin It will be understood that this is a matter calculated to inspire the Government with a certain amount of anxiety." The following is the result of M. Mévil's inquiry into a

state of affairs which he says might one day become a serious menace for French domination in North Aftica. Notwithstanding the satisfactory economic condition of Algeria and the comparativ prosperity of the natives in consequence of a good harvest, the Arab population mani fests the greates hostility towards the French. There have been numerous robberies in many places, particularly of cattle, as well as the murder of several Europeans--a state of affairs which has naturally excited much feeling among the French settlers in the interior, where they live in the midst of a population 20 times as numerous as themselves. The tele- graph brings daily accounts of fresh attacks, and two days ago the gendarmes were mal- treated by a furious crowd of Arabs at Ain Bessam. These incidents are in no way due to any relaxation of administrative surveil lance. It is not impossible that the crimes which are taking place in Algeria have some connection with the revival of fanaticism now manifest throughout all North Africa, "which Germany regards with less apprehension than we do, and which she seems even to encour- age by her attitude towards the Moroccan Government. We have reason to be on our guard in that direction also. The Maghzen has assumed airs towards us and taken pro- ceedings such as it had never taken before, even last year at the most critical stage of the Moroccan crisis.

“The inhabitants of Tafilet, supported is their hostility towards our commercial penetration, resort to all sorts of threats and intrigues to boycott the products transported by oar railway. . . . The tranquility of the economic life of a part of Algeria is thus daily threatened. Besides, the Berates of Tafilet spare no pains to induce the tribes subject to us on the frontier to leave our territory and even to join in the attack upon us. This is a thoroughly intolerable state of affairs. It is known that in the north the disposition. of the Moroccan authorities towards us is scarcely better. We can hardly count upon anything more than their inaction. ... ‘I am told that in the settlement of these questions, both in the north and south of our frontier region, the Governor is determined to maintain his composure. At, the same time the Charbonnier affair has shown us what can be secured from the Maghzcn by an energetic demonstration. If the Moroccan Government does not accede to our very moderate demands, which are but too well justified, we shall remember that a strong policy is often necessary at Fez. As will be seen, the Moroccan question still reserves for us more than one surprise and difficulty, as we still have adversaries who know well how to embroil it. Let us be on our guard, since our security in North Africa depends exclusively upon our own vigilance."

The same journal publishes telegrams from Algiers and Constantinople dealing with the effervescence among the Arab population. According to the statement made by the lieutenant in command of the gendarmerie at Ain Beasam, the attack made upon them by the Arabs was unprovoked and took place with, a suddennnes that betrayed premeditation and concert. During the mélée that followed one of the sheikhs was particularly prominent in inciting the crowd. According to the despatch from Constantine, the audacity of the native bandits is increasing daily. Indeed' they now extend their operations almost to the gates of that town. Quite recently several travelled were stoned by natives, and Borne of them were fired upon just outside the town.

div.head: K.H.S.
div.p: Dr. Keatiuge has resigned the post of honorary secretary and treasurer to the Khedivial Horticultural Society.

div.head: French Cable Ship.
div.p: The French cableship Arago, which laid the cable between Mauritius, Reunion, and Madagascar, left Port Said on Saturday afternoon for Tropez and Havre.

div.head: H M. S. Terrible.
div.p: 11. M’s cruiser Terrible, which recently damaged her propeller shaft badly in Chinese waters, is expected at Suez tomorrow in tow of a British merchant steamer.

div.head: Accident to A Liner.
div.p: The P. and 0. S.S. Sardinia, from London and Marseilles, with 183 passengers, reached Port Said on Friday with a screw blade broken. She has entered Sherif Docks for repairs.

div.head: Beginning of Judicial Year.
div.p: Judge Took, who has just returned from leave, presided on Saturday at the first sitting of the Mixed Tribunal of First Instance of the judicial year 1906-7. Some two hundred oases are down for hearing.

div.head: Honour for Berlitz Schools.
div.p: M. Edouard Wellhoff. general manager of the Berlitz Schools, has been decorated with the Legion of Honour in recognition of the success which the Berlitz system scored at St. Louis World’s Fair.

div.head: S.S. Osmanleh s Fast Steaming.
div.p: The new Khedivial Mail twin screw steamer Osmanieh arrived at Alexandria yesterday at 4 p.m. with a full complement of passengers, having made a record run from the. Piraeus in 28} hours, equal to an average speed of S0£ statute mile9 per hour. The vessel is remarkably steady at sea, and her absence from vibration is especially; pleasing to passengers.

div.head: Exodus X, 22.
div.p: An unfortunate contretemps occurred at the evening service in St. Mark’s Church yesterday, when, during the singing of that beautiful hymn of Cardinal Newman, “Lead Kindly Light,” the electric light went out. The choir, however, showed great presence of mind, and sang through the hymn without a break, and after a few prayers an exit was made from the darkness, illuminated by the faint gleams of two oil-lamps.

div.head: Fallen Heroes.
div.p: A dramatic scene was witnessed at Aldershot this day week, when, consequent on the War Stores Commission revelations, First-class Staff- Sergeant Major Beavan and Staff Sergeant Mills, A.S.C., were discharged from the Army for misconduct under paragraph 1805, XI, King’s Regulations, and ordered to leave the barracks at once. The blow fell very hard on the Sergeant-Major. On the breast of his tunic he could display six medals and eight clasps including the distinguished conduct medal, the Queen and King’s medals, the Sudan medal, the Khedive’s Star, and the good conduct medal. All these he had to hand over to his guard. He has had twenty-two years’ service, and because of his excellent career in South Africa he had been recommended for a commission, and the recommendation had been approved. He was on the point of being promoted when the War Stores inquiry shattered his hopes.
NEW EGYPTOLOGICAL BOOK.

Ancient Records of Egypt. By James Henry Breasted, Ph.D. Vol. IV. (University of Chicago Press. 13s. 6d.)—Professor Breasted completes his Egyptian work with this volume He has now given us a history, and four volumes of the documents, from inscriptions and papyri, on which the history is founded. All that remains to make these labours generally available is the complete index which is announced to be about to follow. Vol. IV. contains the records of seven dynasties (XX.-XXVI.), a period of something more than six hundred years. The Twentieth Dynasty may be fixed, with approximate accuracy, as beginning about 1200 B.C. It is the Rameside dynasty, and though it covers not much more than a century, its records occupy considerably more than half of this volume. It is to this period that the famous "Papyrus Harris” belongs. This papyrus is the largest (133 ft. long) and the most sumptuous of all that have come down to ns. It gives an elaborate account of the property and income of the gods as these were on the death of Rameses III. (1198 1167). It is almost needless to say that this ^record, which Professor Breasted has carefully translated, is of the greatest value; the average reader, however, will find the concluding sections in which the King recounts the circumstances in which the dynasty rose into power most interesting. Another noteworthy document is the “Harem Conspiracy.” This refers to the same reign. One of the Queens of Rameses III. sought to obtain the succession for her son. The story is one that occurs over and over again in Oriental records, and we are at once reminded of the intrigues which troubled the last day8of David. That, too, is not a pleasing story; but the “Harem Conspiracy,” so far as we are able to discern it3 outlines, has a far worse appearance. In $499 556 we have legal documents relating to the tomb robberies. A list of the tombs, etc., inspected is given, beginning with that of Amenhotep I. This was found uninjured, and so were molt of the others. The pyramid of King Sebekemsaf, a petty Sovereign of the sixteenth century, was found to have suffered most. The later Kings left few records behind them. For the Twenty sixth Dynasty, the latest of the native Kings, though it lasted for nearly a century and a half, about forty pages suffice.
WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY
the international problem.

Cologne, October 21. The "Cologne Gazette” refutes the assertion that before the commencement of the Wireless Telegraphy Conference the German Government had asked the French Government to insist on stations employing the Marconi systems on board French ships accepting wireless messages of other systems. This information is baseless, as well as the assertions concerning the pretended anti-British controversies. The German delegates are endeavouring, as well as the rest, to arrive at a satisfactory conclusion in this matter.

This international problem is one of the most difficult. No negotiations have been carried on with any Power which have not been entered into with the others at the same time. It is a great error to pretend that a German victory at the Conference would mean a British defeat. It is hard to see in what sense this could be. (Reuter•)
SELBY ABBEY.
DESTROYED BY FIRE.
London. October 20.

Selby Abbey has been completely destroyed by fire. The flames spread from the gas engine working the organ. An explosion occurred which blew out the north transept window. The famous Norman nave and beautiful choir were gutted. (Peuttter)

Selby Abbey is part of an abbey built by the Benedictine monks in the 10th century, and founded by William the Conqueror, being the only mitred abbey, except St. Mary’s Abbey, whose ruins are one of the sights of York, north of the Trent. It is a magnificent cruciform structure 300 feet long and 60 feet wide. The nave is one of the finest 8p6oimens of Norman architecture, the choir is noted for its handsome decorations, and beyond it is a very beautiful lady chapel. Near the close of the 17th century the south transept was destroyed by the fall of the upper part of the central ower.
NEW MILITARY APPOINTMENT.
London, October 20.
It is understood that General Sir William Nicholson will be appointed Chief of the General Staff. {Reuter)

General Sir William Nicholson, K. C. £., gained his commission in the Royal Engineers in 1865 at the age of twenty. He served in the Afghan War of 1878 80 and with the Candahar field force in the following year. He displayed great bravery on the march to Candahar, which gained for him the brevet rank of major, the medal with three' clasps, and the bronze decoration. He was also con8picnons in the Egyptian campaign of 1882, including the battle of Tel cl Kebir, and was decorated with the fourth class order of the Osmanieh and the Khedive's Star, He was assistant adjutant general to headquarters daring the Burmese expedition of 1886-87, when he was promoted to the brevet rank of lien- tenant-colonel and received the medal with clasp, and he was chief of the staff of the Tirah expeditionary force of 1897-00, for which services he was made K.C.B. From 1898 to 1899 he was adjutant general in India and from 1899 to 1900 he served in South Africa as military secretary to the commander-in-chief, during which period he was twice mentioned in the despatches, received the medal with five clasps, and was promoted to the rank of major-general. From 1904 to 1905 he was director-general of mobilisation and military intelligence, and he spent the following year as chief British military attaché to the Japanese army.
DEATH OF AN IRISH M.P.
London, October 11.
Colonel E. J. Saunderson, M.P., is dead.
{Reuter)

Colonel the Rt. Hon. Edward James Saun- derson had been Conservative Member of Parliament for Armagh County, North, since 1885, and Cavan County Lieutenant since 1900. He was the son of Colonel A. Saunderson, M.P., Castle Saunderson,and grandson, by his mother, of the 6’h Lord Farnham. He was born in 1837 and at the age of twenty-eight married Helena Emily de Moleyns, daughter of the 3rd Lord Ventry. He served for several years in the Royal Irish Fusiliers, and in 1859 was High Sheriff of Cavan Connty. He commenced his political career as M. P. for Cavan Coanty, which he represented from 1865 to 1874. From 1901 to 1903 he was Grand Master of Belfast Orangemen, which post he resigned owing to lack of support.

div.head: TRAIN ON FIRE.
ACCIDENT TO LUXOR EXPRESS
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Keneh, Monday.

A frst-class carriage of the express train which left Luxor for Cairo at half-past five yesterday caught fire by the explosion of a lamp in one of the compartments. The train was immediately brought to a standstill and the burning carriage detached about three kilometres south of Kift.

The villagers were called out to assist in getting the flames under, and the inspector in charge of the Assouan district appeared on the scene very promptly. Energetic measures were taken and after hard work met with success. Three Italians distinguished themselves by the coolness and the effectiveness with which they worked. The carriage was put into a siding at Kift, and the train arrived at Keneh after a delay of two hours.
No one has been injured.

div.head: PRINCE AND PRINCESS OF WALES.
div.p: PROBABLE VISIT TO EGYPT.

It is rumoured that after the opening of the newly-constituted Transvaal Parliament at Pretoria, which will be attended in State by the Prince and Princess of Wales, their Royal Highnesses will, again honour Egypt with a visit.
PRINCE GEORGE AT PORT SAID.

The Danish S.S. Birmania is expected to arrive at Port Said on Friday next, having on board Prince George of Greece, ex-High Commissioner of Crete, accompanied by Prince Valdemar and other princes of the Royal House of Denmark, who embarked on the steamer at Copenhagen. Prince George and his companions are to make a long journey in the Far East, and will first of all visit Siam.
A CONSTITUTION FOR EGYPT.

"A1 Moayad” and “A1 Lewa” publish a petition, which was submitted to Lord Cromer on the 19th inst., by a number of natives asking for the grant of a Constitution in accordance with the principles of Western civilisation. This step is strongly criticised by Farid Bey in "A1 Lewa” on the ground that, inasmach as Great Britain’s position in Egypt is illegal, the presentation oi the petition to Lord Cromer was tantamount to a recognition of the British here.
THE FRONTIER COMMISSION.

Miralai Ahmed Mnzafir Bey and Mohamed Eftendi Fahmi, Ottoman delegates of the Frontier Commission, are en route to Masu, whence they will proceed by way of the Hedjaz railway to Damascus. From there they will continue to Beyrout, where they will embark for Constantinople.
JUDICIAL CHANGES.
Judge de Sigoyer and Judge Antoniadis, of the Alexandria Mixed Courts, have sent in their resignations.
Judge Prunilres and Judge Pangalos are spoken of as their respective successors.
BREAKDOWN ON S.S. SCOTTISH
PRINCE.
News has just come to hand of the safe arrival at Malta of the S.S. Scottish Prince, which left this port on the 9th inst. bound for Manchester with a cargo of cotton.

It appears that on Saturday week, at 4 a m., when about 120 miles off Malta, the web of the lower pressure crank shaft broke, leaving the ship practically helpless. An attempt was made to work her slowly into port, hot at noon it had to be abandoned, and it was decided to make an effort to repair the damage done, by putting a strap around the shaft. This was successfully done with a band off a mast and steel rod, and by $.30 that evening everything was ready and a start again made. The weather being fine at the time, no difficulty was experienced, and the engines were worked slowly with frequent stops, until within 9 miles of Malts, when a fresh strap had to be put on, hut as this had been made ready in case of emergency it did not take long to place, and by midnight on Sunday the vessel was safely moored.

The place where the accident occurred is in the track of steamers from Malta to Alexandria and where there is very little traffic, and had the weather not been fine at the time, or had the ship drifted to the southward, she would have stood a very poor chance of obtaining any assistance, in the event of her needing it
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Cambridge sailed hence for Manchester on Saturday evening with a general cargo, including 8,017 bales of cotton.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Equateur passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday afternoon, and is due here to-morrow morning with mails from Europe.
The Moss liner Menep'hah left Alexandria yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta* with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 4,344 bales of cotton.

A few days ago we drew attention to the questions that hid recently been asked in the House of Commons on the extraordinary growth of drink imports into the Sudan. That the question fully deserves the attention of the House of Commons nobody will deny, and its serious aspect becomes more apparent when the figures are contrasted with the extent of the population of the Sudan. Spirits to the amount of 561 tons, valued at L.E. 119,738, came into the Sudan in 1904, while the value of the liquor imports last year was L.E. 84,000.

According to Lord Cromer’s latest report the population of the country is estimated at a total of 1,853,000 persons, of whom 10,396 are foreigners, viz, 2,787 Europeans, 8,209 Abys- sinians, Egyptians, Indians, etc. His Lordship remarks: “The point moat to be noted in the calculations submitted by the local authorities is the very large proportion of children. Thu3, of 90,000 persons in the province of Dongola it is estimated that over 43.000, or thirty-two per cent, of the total, are children under nine years of age.”

The adult male population of the Sudan bears, therefore, a very small proportion to the estimated total of 1,853,000 given by Lord Cromer, and yet in 1904 spirits to the value of L.E. 119,738 were imported. It need scarcely be pointed out that this immoderate use of spirits by savage or semi-civilised people in a tropical climate is a far deadlier and more insiduous foe than plague, pestilence, or famine. Savage races are not decimated but exterminated by strong drink, and the enormous increase in this class of imports is-a terrible reflection on the evils attendant on what is called civilisation. Lord Cromer recognised the significance of these figures, and in a penultimate report he remarked: “The valuation of L.E. 119,738 would appear to be unusually high. I am, however, informed that the balk of spirituous liquors, which come into the Sudan, is of good quality.”

But surely this is only the palliation of an evil which ought to have been checked long before it assumed its present gigantic proportions. If it is possible for the authorities to 8top a newspaper like “Al Minbar” from entering the Sudan on the ground of the dangerous character of its political opinions, surely it is far more incumbent on them to prevent the huge growth in the imports of spirits! But the official standpoint probably is that the criticism of "Al Minbar” is far more deleterious to the mind of the Sudanese than £119,738 worth of spirits can be to their bodies, which is an indirect compliment to "Al Minbar.” ,
ARRIVAL OF IMPERATUL TRAJAN.

The Imperatul Trajan, the first of the new Roumanian linesteamers between Constanza and Alexandria, arrived in Alexandria at seven o’clock this morning from the former port by way of Constantinople and Smyrna. The vessel is a splendid steamer of 12,000 tons displacement net register and 7,300 H.P. She is quite new, having been built this year at St.Nazaire, and has accommodation for 115 first class and 45 second class passengers, with splendid steerage accommodation. She will leave on .Wednesday at 6 p.m. on her return journey. Her arrival at Constanza will be in connection with the Orient and Ostend expresses.
Captain Commander John Coanda, direotor- general of the company, was on board.
THE KHEDIVE.

The Khedive arrived at Ras el Tin from Montazah at 9.30 a.m. He will entertain this evening to an iftar Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha and a number of high officials on the retired list, after which he will return to Montazah.
KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.

The Khedive has conferred the second class of the Order of the Medjidieh on Morgan Agha, who attended the Khedivah Mother daring her stay at Constantinople. Hu Highness has also conferred the 3rd class of the Order of the Osmanieh on his physician, Dr. Kaotwki, and the 4th class of the Order of the Osmanieh on Sheikh Mohamed Osman, of the Ma’ieh Sanieb. The 4th class of the Order of the Medjidieh has been conferred on Mnstapha Rahmi, moawen to the Khassa ; Sheikh Hamid&llah, chief of the Montazah Yakieh, and Mulazim Sani Mohamed, of the Ma’ieh staff.
THE PLAGUE.

Through a clerical error on Saturday, we announced that a case of plague and two deaths therefrom had occurred at Cairo, whereas it should have been Suez. No cases of plague have occurred in Cairo for some time.
To-day’s bulletin records a death at Alexandria, a fatal case at Port Said, and a recovery at Suez.
MUSEUM FOR TEWFIKIEH COLLEGE. .

A small museum is being added to the Tewfikieh College, where a scientific society was recently formed. The society is divided into four branches, antiquarian, geological, botanical and entomological), and will be of considerable value if it teaches Egyptian boys how to use their eyes take and interest in and scientific problems.

div.head: THE UNIVERSITY SCHEME.
div.p: (From a Correspondent.)

The circular of. the committee formed for the establishment of a national university, a translation of which was recently printed in the "Egyptian Gazette,” is remarkable for its restraint and for its common sense. When the proposal was first mooted there were not looking those among us who spoke of Pan- Islam; and it is probable that there were some who may have thought that the movement offered further scope for political intrigue. The committee, "however, have proved themselves to be influenced by a higher patriotism, and to have the true interests of their country at heart. "The university that we desire to create is to be absolutely scientific and literary. Its doors will be wide open for all desirous of learning, irrespective of origin and religion. It will have no connection at all with politics, or even with men who occupy themselves with politics. “Here indeed is true patriotism: a patriotism which considers the welfare of “Egyptians,” and not of any particular sect or section of the very composite Egyptian nation. A patriotism which is above party.

The national university movement is not another proof of "unrest.” Those who are. most closely connected with the present educational system of Egypt are most aware of its defects; and among the first to admit the inadequacy of the present system are those most largely responsible for it. The Adviser to the Ministry of Education and Lord Cromer both admit that the Government system does not meet all the requirements of the country. The Government primary, secondary, and higher schools are maintained for a special purpose- the education of a class of men who will be able to fill posts in the different Government departments. The education policy of the Egyptian Government is to provide for itself a class of young Egyptians who will be able to assist in the administration of the State. These men are theoretically dedicated to the service of the State, and the cost of their education is, for the most part, borne by the State, the student only paying L.E. 15 oat of L.E. 78. This being the Government policy, the education provided is directed almost entirely towards the special end in view, and is, therefore, not entirely suited to the student who does not intend to enter Government service. In Lord Cromer’s words: "The

Government system of schools, which dates back to a period long before the British occupation, is designed to provide in the main a European education. The system was not conceived, and cannot be regarded, as a complete expression of the national needs in the matter of education, nor can it be taken as representing the lines along which educational development should advance indefinitely.”
Present System of Education.

Lord Cromer has repeatedly said that the system of education, at present provided by the Government, is of a special character and intended for a special purpose: that it is not a system which is suited to all; that a more "national” system is necessary, but the finances of the State do not admit of this more popular education being provided by the Government, that it must be provided by private effort.

“Today,” we read in the circular before us, “Egyptians are beginning to feel that there is in their education a very large gap which must be filled.” Egyptians realise that there is something wanting, something that is not given by the Government; but until something better is provided Egyptians mast be content with what they can get in the Government schools. Not is the position of the Egyptian reformer an easy one. The Government provide education at a fifth of its cost; is it surprising that private enterprise finds it difficult to compete with the State 1 Is it, under these circumstances, surprising that the committee for the establishment of the national university are doubtful of the success of their movement 1

What is it that our education reformers desire 1 And could not the Government itself do something to "fill the gap?” “In order that Egypt may be admitted to the ranks of civilised countries, it Joes not suffice that the majority of its population know I19W to read and write, nor, farther, that a class be found for professional knowledge, such as doctors, lawyers, engineers, etc.” There must be encouragement given to those who desire to study for the sake of “Knowledge” alone, who desire that Egypt should take a place in the world among those states which produce the great writers, the great scientists, the great historians, the great discoverers of this age. "Bat what is truly astonishing is this: There is' not in the whole of Egypt a class where are taught the literary, scientific, and philosophical works of the best known and most appreciated in Europe of the ancient Arab authors 1” Is a great historic language to be allowed to die without an effort on the part of this enlightened Government of Egypt 1 A language with its vast treasury of literature and philosophy. Is there no room for snob- a study in the Government curriculum 1
An Important Reform.

An important reform has recently been made in the Government education system. The Primary certificate has ceased to have its ancient value, and the Secondary schools have undergone an important modification. A student who has obtained the Primary certificate now finds that the Government offices are not yet open to him, that he must prolong his studies yet a little longer; he must enter the Secondary schools.

The work in the Secondary schools is now divided into two parts. A student on entering first follows what is practically the old syllabus for two years, when he finds that be must take an examination. If he is successful in this he finds himself at the parting of three ways: he may apply for a government post of minor importance, or h) may elect to remain at the Secondary school either on the literary or scientific side. The first leads to the School of Law and thence either to a professional life, or to a post of some importance in one or other of the Ministries of Law, Interior, or Finance; if, however, he elects to follow a more scientific form of study, he chooses the second, and ultimately finds himself qualified to enter the School of Medicine or the School of Engineering, with ultimately a career before him either in government service or as a professional man. To pat it shortly, the three years’ study of the Secondary schools has been reduced to two years, and an intermediate school has been added between the Secondary and Higher schools with a two years’ course of study.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha, who will act as Governal General of the Sudan until Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha’s arrival at Khartoum early next month, left Cairo for the Sudan capital yesterday. He will afterwards leave for Kordofan. _
Henry Pasha, Adjutant-General of the Egyptian Army, has been suffering from a severe attack of dysentery, and left for England yesterday on sick leave.

Among the arrivals by the S.S. Semiramis from Trieste this morning were the Premier, Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, Judge Sanders, Padua Bey and Mme Padoa, Mr. V. Aghion, Mr. Mallison, Mr. Bauer, Mr. J. Pihs, etc

The Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern, which arrived from Marseilles and Naples this morning, had a large number of passengers, including Princess Fawks Fouad, Princess Ismail, Hassan Pasha Rafki, Coant and Countess de Crailsheim, Baron Jacques de Menasoe, Baron and Baroness E. de Menasoe, Hon. Iddiogs, Osman Bey Cherifi Consol Wunderlich, Dr. Valensin, Captain Braoken- ridge, Mr. Claar Aghion, Mr. Joseph Aghion, Mr. A. Tilohe, Mr. G. B. Alderson, Mr. and Mrs. de Vries.
The King of Italy h&9 conferred the Grand Cordon of the Crown of Italy on H. R Saba Pasha. The Postmaster General is to be heartily congratulated on his well-merited decoration.
We are glad to learn that Jonkheer Van der Does de Villebois, who has been seriously ill, is now convalescent, and will be able to return to Cairo about the end of next month.
The salary of Mr. A. L. Webb, C.M.G., has been raised to L E. 2,000.
Mr. Dupois will leave for the Sudan early in November.
Miralai Owen Bey and Naoum Bey Shukëir are expected to arrive at Cairo next Thursday from Nekhl Fort.
Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank will leave Marseilles on Saturday for Cairo vi& Port Said by the P. & 0. S.S. Caledonia.
Jadge H. W. Halton is on his way out to Egypt, returning from leave.

The marriage recently took place at Christ Chnroh, Cinoinatti, of Judge Kershaw, Cairo, to Miss Anne Winston Price, granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Rodgers, of Covington, Ky. Tha bridegroom is the son of the late Sir John Kershaw, who was a close friend of King Edward. He met Miss Price in Cairo when she was travelling abroad a year ago.
MM. Raphael, Léon, and André Suarès are expected back in Cairo on the 7th November. The date of Mme Félix Snarls’ return has not yet been fixed.
Mme Luigi Steinechneider is leaving Marseilles for Egypt by the North German Lloyd S.S. Hohetzollern on the 31st inst.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Fort Said, we notice: Mr. Roux de Vence, Capt. Wettre, Capt. Lonsdale, Capt. Murray, Capt. and Mrs. Collision Morley, Mrs. and Miss Shakoor, Mr. B. J. Boyd, Mr. and Mme Giulio de Castro, Cav. Enrico Maoehia, Mr. Maylard, Pasteur Monel, Mr. Betts, Mr. and Mrs. C. Crossland, Mr. Griwes, Mr. Hodges, Mr, Knight, Lient. R. E. Platt, Lieut. R R. Pratt, M£ D. Seleton and family. Dr. Voronoff, Major Wynne, Col. Bingley, Capt. Low, Mr. K Williams, Mr. Cheeltam. Mr. Vincore, Mr. Richmond, Mr. and Mrs. Houston, Dr. and Mrs. Murile, Miss Howes.

Le Cairo, 20 Octobre. Un tdldgramme de Londres annonoe qne la Banqne d’Angleterre a klevk bier' son tanx d'esoompte de 5 k 6 %. Ls dernier bila-', public avant hier, montrait nne augmentation de £ 490,000 sur la reserve de billets et de £56,000 sur la reserve mdtalliqne. La proportion de la reserve aux engagements ktait de 37 3/4 poor oent. En prenant oette mesure exceptionnelle, la Banqne entend done protkger effioaoement sa reserve contre les nonvelles brfeohes qni pourraient Ini Ctre (sites par les retraits d’or pour Tdtranger. Par suite, le tanx d’esoompte sur le marohd libre a baussd d’emblde de 4 7/8 a 5 7/8. An Stock Exchange, la Coosolidd anglais a, en oonsdqaenoe, baissk de non moins de 1/2 livre k 85 7/8 et TUnifide d’autant k 104. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 k 27 1/8. L’Agrioole, la Daira et la Delta Light sont res toes inrarides k leurs cours prkokdents. A Paris, 1’aotion Credit Fonoier Egyptian a retrograde de 3 frapes k 778 et la Basque d’Athknes de 1 franc k 144. Impressionnd, toot ensemble, par la extraordinaire du tanx d’escompte k Londre°, par les mauvais oonrs des place; dirigeantes d’Europe et par la baisse du ooton en Amdriqne, notre marchd a Mi, ce matin, k an moovo- ment de frayeur et a debate k des prix sea- siblement inferieurs aux cours de clOture sou tenus de la veille,avec tendance k la baisse sur peique toute la ligne de la cote. Cette petite panique, asseznatnie’le du rests, n’a pas ete toutefois ernsistante. On s’est res- saisi et Ton s’est arrtte snr la pente d’une depression aveugle en prenant en consideration qn’aprhs tout oe renohdrissement innsite da loyer de i’argent etait dft sertout aux be loins exciptioanelsde 1’Bgypte, determine; par les prix inesperes auxqaels >se vend le cotoa, e’est-k-dire par la prosperite et la riohesse oroissantes du pay;. Ainsi qua nous Tavions fait remarquer il y a quelques j oars, il a ete oalouie qa’il nom fact, k cat effet, environ 5 1/2 millions de livres de plus qne l’annee precedents en se basant sur nne remits de 6 1/4 millions de oautars. Or, one bonne part de ce snrerolt de numeraire noas restera et sera certainement employee dans les valenrs. Ainsi done, pares qa’il faat, pour l’instaut, payer Tor 1 % de plus qu’on na s’y attendait, il ne s’eusuit nnllement qu’il y ait peril en la dsmeure et qa’il faille faire snbir aux bonnes va'enrs locales one depreciation irraisonnee. Tout an contrai-e, celles-ci sont appeiees k ne pas tarder k profiter de la ciroonstance mkme qui les a fait passa- gkrement baisser anjourd’bui. An demenrant, les aohats ont fini par primer les ventes, et la cldtnre a ete ferme. Dans le compartiment des Banqnes, la National a debate k 26 15/16 poor ffeohirk 26 7/8 et dCturer k 27. L’Agrioole a molli k 9 13/16, la Cassa di Sconto k 232-233 et la Banqne d’Orient k 135. Le Comptoir Financier est reste k 6 7/8. L’aotion Credit Fonoier a ete ramenee k 778-779 ; la part de fondatenr a perdu 10 franos k 980. La Daira a faibli k 16 3/4. L \ Bebdra a ete traitee a 39 3/4 40. La Nile Land est revenue k 16. L’aotion Enterprise and Development a ete eohangee k 12 3/4-13/16 et la put de fondatenr k 21 3/4. Les Improvements se sont alourdis k5 15/16. Le Wardan Estate a progresse k 6 7/8 15/16. L’Allotment a debate k 3 3/4 pour baisser k 3 19/32 et olfttnrer k 3 5/8-11/16. l’Union Fon- oikre a perdu 1/16 k 6 3/16. L’action Entreprises Immobilikres et Travaux s est tenne k 4 7/16 ; la port de fondatenr a rdrotione k 94. La Delta Light a faibli k 12 1/16, lea Jonis- sances Erux da Cairo k 267 ot les Automobile k 6 3/16 1/4. Les Ciments ont bknefioik de 2 franos k 70. L’aotion prlviWgide T/ampay i d’Alexandrie s’est rafformie k 191, de mfime qne la Dividends k 337. Dans le gronpe des valenrs bdtelikres, les Nuugovioh ont ete offsrts k 17 15/16 pour clAtnrer k 17 15/16 18. Les Egyptian ont re oule k 6 13/16. Les Upper Egypt ont ete bien tenask 5 1/4 5/16. La part de fondatenr National Hotel a faibli k 69. Parmi les petites valenrs, la Delta Land a debate k 3 3/4 pour fleohir k 3 11/16 et remon- ter a 3 13/16, achetears. Les Estates ont ete ramenes k 2 pour finir k 2-2 1/16 la part de fondatenr a baisse jusqn’k It 1/8 poor ol6tu- rer aux abords de 15. Les New Egyptian ont molli k 33 sh , les Constraotions k 1 1/2 et les Abdy k 1 1/4-5/16. Lei Salt and Soda ont perdu 1 shelling k 23. On nous demande de divers c6tfs des explications sur le mouvement qni s’est dessind C38 jours derniers snr les notions de la Socidte Anonyme du Behdra, qni restaient depuis si longtemps inertes. Nous espdrons fitre sons pen en mesure de donner k cos lectenrs les informations les plus preoises h ce sujet. La direction dn journal ‘‘L’Egypte’’ nous prie de constater qne o'est par suite d'une regrettable errenr de transmission tdldphoni- qne qua, dans l’eiition de ce matin, elle a annonod qne M. Baehler, directenr des Egyptian Hotels, fondait un nonvean Trnst d’hd tela egyptiens. Il s’agissait de M. Baner, di- reotenr dn National Hotel. L’errenr se recti- fiait par la simple lecture de Tinformation donnea. Lsi aotionnaires de la Societe Anonyme Agricole et Induitrielle d’Egypte sont oonvo- qnds en assemble gdad-ale extraordinaire poor le 27 Novembre proohiin, an slkge social k Anvers. A l’ordre dn jonr: T Aagmeota'ion da capital; emission an pair poor les anoiens aotionnaire?; 2° Emission d’obligations.

Persona importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sedan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. !^8283a-30-IO-906

The Tear, is an important ukase entitles all Russians without distinction of class to enter the public service, except Siberian and Asiatio races. He repeals a number of vexatious peasants’ laws. Peasants will henceforth be free to choose their place of residence, and will receive passports for unlimited periods. ( Tenter.)
An ukase has been promulgated admitting all to Government offices, and granting equality to all before the law. (Havas)

Yesterday's ukase does not include Jews and Poles. An Imperial order issued simultaneously reminds the peasants of the severe penalties inflicted on those refusing to undergo military service. The general effect of yesterday's ukase is to relieve the peasants of the onerous authority of the communes. The peasants can retain the benefits of the communal system during employment elsewhere and can leave a commune without its consent and join another. ("Reuter)

div.head: NEW FRENCH MINISTRY.PORTFOLIO TOR GENERAL PICQUART.

div.p: It appears certain that General Picquart will be the Minister of War in the new Cabinet. M. Clemencean has undertaken to form a new Cabinet. He urged M. Bourgeois to retain the office of Foreign Minister, but he has declined owing to the state of his health. ( U.)
M. Clemencean has commenced his measures for the formation of the Ministry. It appears that General Picquart will be appointed Minister of War. (Havea)
The First Foreign regiment at Sidi Bel- Abbas has been ordered to be in readiness to proceed South. General Liautey has rejoined his post at Ain Sefra. ( Tenter)
The first battalion of Turcos have received orders to bold themselves in readiness to march southward. f Hanot)
Great Britain and France, to-day, signed definitely the New Hebrides convention, which was concluded in February. (Tenter)
Count Goluchoweky has resigned owing to differences in the Hungarian Cabinet. {It.)
Herr von Tschirschky had a' half-hour's interview with Signor Tittoni. ( Tenter)

The jury of the State of Ohio, after 32 hours’ deliberation, has found the Standard Oil Com' pan/ to be guilty of conspiracy with a view to restrain the trade, since 6th July 1903. The law makes each day’s business a separate offence punishable with a fine not exceeding 5,000 dollars. ( Reuter)

div.head: THE METRIC SYSTEM.MR. LLOYD GEORGE’S OPINION.

div.p: Mr. Lloyd George, interviewed on the metric subject, admitted the harm the present system did to oar foreign trade, but he thought that legislative introduction of the metric system would be a mistake unless it was demanded by the commercial classes; in that case the change could be easily effected It would cause temporary inconvenience, but the trade of the conn- try would benefit from it. {Reuter)
The banking house of Messrs. F. MacFadyen & Co. has suspended payment. {Reuter)
It is officially stated that Bali Island has been pacified. The expedition is terminated. {Reuter)
The Brooklyn has been refloated. The cyclone has abated. The damage done here amounts to about 2,000,000 dollars. (Reuter)

The cyclone was the severest within the memory of the present generation. The wind travelled at 80 miles an hour. The waves engulfed 35 lighters in the harbour. Buildings were shaken as if by an earthquake. The trains were washed from the line. {Reuter)

The cyclone wrought great havoc at Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. The physical features of certain parts of Salvador are completely changed. Numerous fatalities occurred. The Salvadorian warship Izaloo is lost (R.)

The Brooklyn, which was driven ashore during the recent cyclone at Havana, belongs to the second class of the United States’ armoured cruisers. She was laid down towards the end of 1893 and at her trials did 83 knots at a mean speed of 21.92 knots with a boiler pressure of 100 lb3. and 138 to 140 revolutions, she being very light at the time. She has a total displacement of 9,215 ton, with a coal capacity which enables her to steam 5,110 knots at the average speed of 10 knots per hour. Her armament consists of eight 8in. breechloader in pairs in the barbette turrets, arranged lozenge-wise; twelve 5in. quickfirers behind 4in. shields; twelve 6in. projecting quick-firers; four lin. projecting; four machine guns; two Sin. field quick-firers; and four Whitehead torpedo tubes. She has a full complement of 517 men. It will be remembered that the Brooklyn paid a visit to Alexandria in May last, during which her officers made themselves very popular here.
Willemstad, (Curacao) October 21. Eleven days’ gales and floods have devastated the Islands. Many vessels have been wrecked.{Reuter}
he steamer V& nag, leaving the harbour, struck a mine and sank. Two hundred passengers perished. {Reuter)

div.head: THE LUTIN DISASTER.RECOVERY OF BODIES IMPOSSIBLE.

div.p: The manhole of the Latin is open, and the boat is full of water. From this it is concluded that the automatic closing apparatus failed to work. {Reuter)
The British warships nave left.

The French Minister, M. Thomson, bade farewell to the captains, and, at a luncheon at which they were entertained on board a French cruiser, he thanked them for their assistance and courtesy. M. Thomson descended in a submarine close to the Latin, and remained there for 50 minutes.{Reuter)
It has been found impossible to remove the bodies from the Latin. (Havas)

The Latin is one of the four submarines of the Farfadet type. Launched in 1902, the vessel is 135 ft. 7in. in length, h«s a diameter of 9ft. 6 in., and displaces 185 tons. Her speed on the surface is about twelve knots, and submerged the vessel can attain eight knots. The motive power is derived from electric accumulators, the propeller making 250 revolutions at full speed. She is armed with four torpedo launching gear.

A tremendous conflagration broke out here at an early hour this morning. The Union Bank and a number of buildings of the leading banks, insurance companies, and hotels, and other buildings, have been destroyed. {Reuter)
Twenty-three Chinamen were dashed to pieces through the snapping of the cable of the descending cage of Simmer and Jack East mine. {Reuter)
Rugby. The South Africans beat Somerset by 14 points to nil. {Reuter}

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN PRESS.
div.p: , EULOGY OF ITSELF.
"A1 Moayad” writes:—

There is now in Egypt a strong and influential power, which is the native Pro’s. We do not say that the Native Press is infallible, but we boldly confess that it is a powerful agent with a voice that touches the heartstrings and penetrates through the ears to the brains.

It may sometimes err, but generally it hits the mark. Moreover, the nation confides in its opinions relies on the truth of its patriotism, and is, on the whole, strongly attached to it. It is well known that the Occupation has possessed absolute influence in every department of the Government by means of the advisers, and that nobody is free except the Press, which is really the last resort of the native in adversity and misery, and through which he can air his grievances. All this his Lordship has already known and even declared in his report on the Egyptian Press when he said that the latter watches over his works. Bat his Lordship saw, after the Akaba and the Denishwai affairs, that the influence of the Press had grown fearfully powerful, and therefore wished to stifle its growth. Thus he accused it of falsehood and said it was the moat subtle Press in the whole world in inventing lies. Not only this, but even his Lordship’s agent said that it raised its tre-mendous voice, that alarmed every English employé in Egypt, by bribery. Then his Lord- ship began to secretly threaten the freedom of the Egyptian Press.

For these reasons, some people thought that, after his return, his Lordship might give great attention to the question of the Native Press; and many were the conjectures respecting what his Lordship might do.
The following are the instances of these conjectures.
M Will its present freedom remain“Will his Lordship find a means how to supervise it "Will he restrict it?”

But our confidence in the wisdom of the British Agent and our trust in the strength of his English and original principles, lead us to believe that his Lordship will not injure the freedom of the Press, neither by supervision nor by restriction. |

We have right, by a historical proof, to be assured of the truth and soundness of this confidence. A few years ago, all those who belonged to the British Agency, whether officials or not, found “Al Moayad” a thorn in their sides, and some of them asked his Lordship to bring about its fall by all means. His Lordship then answered that its fall could only be brought about by one of two means. The first was by tempting the publisher of “Ai Moayad” into some snare or other which would cause the fall of the paper. The second | was by patting an end to it in an unconstitutional manner. "The first of these,” said his j Lordship, "is inconsistent with my honour; to the second the Parliament will not agree.”

This historical proof respecting the native | Press, on whose principles the Egyptian Press was organized, shows that his Lordship respects the honourable and free principles of the Press for two reasons—the one a personal motive, and the other a motive founded on educational principles.

Thera is what we expect to be the last act with which his Lordship will crown his services in Egypt We believe his temporary j wrath at the conduct of papers will not lead him to destroy with his own hands the best structure that he built and which is the only comfort for Egyptians.
This is what we hope, if destiny does not throw in our way obstacles that may blight our hopes.

To treat the subject fully, we say that his Lordship has seen, like ail who have given attention to the conduct of the Native Press in the last few years, that the papers are not alike. Of these there are the unimportant that do not spread among the nation; there are also the extreme that go so far as to say there is no good whatever in the English and the Occupation, and sometimes are carried beyond their proper limits by patriotic zeal. Then there are the reasonable that respect truth and mean to be a useful mirror for the nation in every matter of moment. Then there are the extreme in the opposite direction, we mean that absolve the English and injure the feelings of the natives.

These are oar papers and their different kinds, if the English complain of some opinion or language, it cannot be those of a reasonable paper, but of the extreme native papers. So, if his Lordship means to supervise the Press or put restrictions on its liberty, this will be because he is offended at the extreme papers that transgress their patriotic zeal.
Let his Lordship permit ns to talk to him freely and reasonably.

First, it is not right to punish the Egyptian Press for the fault of one single paper. Secondly, his Lordship thinks that an extreme native paper has deserved punishment for transgressing its limits through patriotic zeal. What then should he think with regard to a paper that gees to the opposite extreme and means to hurt Egypt and her sons. If his Lordship sees that he should supervise the Press which will result in preventing the native papers from adopting unreasonable means for sowing the seeds of discontent in the hearts of the natives with the Occupation, and if this supervision also resulted in preventing the other kind of paper, that snatched at every opportunity to injure the feelings of the natives, from inflicting their wounds, then it may be Egypt has not lost by that; for, it has been deprived of the freedom of her free papers, yet it has guaranteed its safety from the painful language that harts the national feelings which is sent daily

to the hearts of the natives by the Occupation papers. Yet it is not wise to use this method. Bat the best way to reach the hearts of the natives and not the bricks is to lesson the violence of the subduing force and to recommend the English officials that work the machine of government to treat the natives kindly and to refuse them none of their just and reasonable demands and to repulse the injuries that have been for many years directed against them by their enemies who try to make people understand that in injuring the national feeling they are only executing the desires of the British Agency, thus leaving the nation in doubt and suspicion. If his Lordship, instead of asking the rough and ragged course that deviates from the honourable English principles, follows the smooth and safe course that we have just pointed out and which coincides with those honourable principles, if his Lordship allows the Native Press to possess its freedom as the only comfort to the country for the misfortune of being occupied by a foreign power, we can guarantee that he Will not find in the native Press what he now finds ; while the excess of the extreme papers will then be a onset of ruin for themselves. On the other hand, if his Lordship supervised or restricted the Press, he will not gain the end he seeks; for the foreign privileges will then help those who wish to utter their opinions under that protection; and if his Lordship tried to resist the effects of that plan from one direction, he certainly cannot meet them from all sides. We will not remind his Lordship of the fact that nothing is more agreeable to man that what he has been refused; thus to deprive the Press of its freedom would inflame the nation, love and zeal for the extreme papers which may cause doubt and lead the young people to such bad acts as he would not now expect. After all we have said, we expect of his Lordship neither supervision nor restrictions, bat, on the other hand, we expect that he should give attention to all that the Press demands, refusing nothing just or reasonable. This, and only this, will make the Press keep to the right path. When, by this course, the nation has gained the fruit of liberty, then will she keep to it, leaving all the unnatural means she used for this end, which those who know not the right path, tried in vain to make her leave.
THE LATE MAJOR L’ESTRANGE JOHNSTONE, M.V.O. General Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, who died In London after an operation on Thursday, September 27, 1906

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company and over 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
